pageContext.description: These were evidently used to line the bottom of crucibles in which they were found. Traces of gravel on this piece. Upper-most side is convex, the other side is practically flat, i.e. excepting for a roughness from casting.
pageContext.surface: Both sides are rough, the flat side is the rougher. The convex side has a number of small holes either from "bubbles" of tiny pebbles in a mould of gravel. There are large bubble holes on the flat side. The roughness of the flat side is levelled down as if from hammer blows.
pageContext.associations: Another similar speciment.,One of a hoard consisting of 7 Palstaves, 1 Winged Celt, 5 Socketed Celts, + 4 "Cakes" of Bronze
pageContext.collection: Worthing Museum,Presented by the late Mr. E. C. Patching
pageContext.site: England,Sussex,Worthing,Ham Road ("40 Acres" Brickfield),4 ft. below surface,Feby 1877
pageContext.toSearch: Ham Road, Worthing, Worthing, West Sussex, UK
